awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Arnav Tripathy is "Enumerative Geometry, Automorphy, and Moonshine." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Shing-Tung Yau.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant served to support a great deal of work importing ideas from high-energy theoretical physics into mathematics. The PI, and collaborators, extended previous ideas for doing so in the following two large areas of mathematical physics: (i) together with D. Berwick-Evans, E. Cliff, N. Ganter, and J. Wen, we continued to develop models for equivariant elliptic cohomology. This fast-moving subject is of great interest to both mathematicians and physics, with applications ranging from representation theory and topology in pure mathematics to the study of new quantum phases of materials in condensed matter physics. Not only have we produced both research papers and expositional materials for more general audiences, we have also successfully organized multiple community-building workshops with particular emphasis on outreach to marginalized communities.
Under the support of this grant, the PI has also (ii) pursued a deep study into mathematical aspects of the study of supersymmetric theories arising in string theory together with S. Kachru, M. Zimet, L. Fredrickson, R. Mazzeo, and others. Strikingly, physical insight promises to provide sharp answers to very deep (and old!) mathematical conjectures, and the beginnings of a large program to do so are detailed in the papers of Kachru-Tripathy-Zimet. In particular, this grant has directly served to support work leading to explicit determinations of metrics on K3 manifolds. Mathematically, this resolves a question of S.-T. Yau from 1982; physically, this represents a substantial improvement in our detailed understanding of some of the first studied models of quantum gravity arising from string theory.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/11/2022
Modified by: Arnav Tripathy
